linkTarget.anchoringText: There are six conventional two-phase flow patterns in horizontal flow conditions, shown in Fig. 1 and known as

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to that preliminary assessment, the minimum flow rate was estimated as 300 million standard cubic feet per day (MMSCFD) with a constant pressure at the outlet of export pipeline of 1100 psig (pounds per square inch, gage). A reduction in required inlet pressure of the pipeline, while maintaining the expected gas flowrate at referred outlet pressure, would increase the operational life of the production well and effectiveness of the well exploitation. Initial parameters of pipeline are given in Table 1. The three Norte de Paria fields (Mejillones, Patao, Dragon), shown in Fig. 1, are defined as dry gas fields; i.e., produced gas does not contain or contains small proportion of condensate and other reservoir liquids. Average water depth of the field is 100 m.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Dragon Field: natural gas reservoir in Venezuela (Pérez et al., 2015)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dragon Field: natural gas reservoir in Venezuela (Pérez et al., 2015)

linkTarget.bib:
Pérez et al., 2015 Pérez
L. Pérez , Marquez, J. Marquez , Rojas, M. Rojas , 2015. Influence of variation of flow in underwater systems and export collection in offshore gas field . Presented at the SPE WVPS 3rd South American Oil and Gas Congress, Maracaibo, Zulia State,

linkTarget.anchoringText: The bathymetry of the gas pipeline, along with PIPESIM™ model layout are presented in Fig. 2. Total pipe length is 101 kilometers and elevation is between -160 m and 20 m. This profile was built on PIPESIM™ according to estimated parameters from previous work (Pérez et al., 2015).

The bathymetry of the gas pipeline, along with PIPESIM™ model layout are presented in Fig. 2. Total pipe length is 101 kilometers and elevation is between -160 m and 20 m. This profile was built on PIPESIM™ according to estimated parameters from previous work (Pérez et al., 2015).

Figure 3 illustrates pressure distribution obtained along the pipeline with initial configuration. Results show that with initial configuration, it would be needed an inlet pressure larger than 1351 psig (94.1 bars) in order to have the minimum 300 MMSCFD flowrate. Figure 4 show that the initial configuration (which indeed served as initial seed at the beginning of this work) has multiple liquid hold-ups with fractions of 50% in average.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: General Pressure Distribution for 300 MMSCFD flow rate and 36-inch diameter

formatted-caption.caption-text: General Pressure Distribution for 300 MMSCFD flow rate and 36-inch diameter

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 3 illustrates pressure distribution obtained along the pipeline with initial configuration. Results show that with initial configuration, it would be needed an inlet pressure larger than 1351 psig (94.1 bars) in order to have the minimum 300 MMSCFD flowrate. Figure 4 show that the initial configuration (which indeed served as initial seed at the beginning of this work) has multiple liquid hold-ups with fractions of 50% in average.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Liquid holdup representation with pipeline profile for d=36 inches

formatted-caption.caption-text: Liquid holdup representation with pipeline profile for d=36 inches

linkTarget.anchoringText: A bar chart is constructed to perform more meaningful analyses (see Fig. 5). It is clear that inlet pressure has to be higher at small diameters and it should decrease by increasing the internal diameter. Trend line shown in Fig. 5 clearly describes this fact. Controversially, liquid holdup is at minimum degree with minimum pipe internal diameter and then, it rises as the diameter increases. Therefore, the optimal pipe diameter should represent a trade-off between both minimum inlet pressure and minimum holdup. Pipes with diameters 24, 26 and 28 inches led to low inlet pressures with a much lower liquid holdup than the initial gas pipeline configuration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Inlet Pressure and internal diameter dependence

formatted-caption.caption-text: Inlet Pressure and internal diameter dependence

linkTarget.anchoringText: Sensitivity analysis was performed to observe the difference in the intensity of liquid holdups between 24, 26 and 28 inches pipes. Figures 6, 7, 8 present the comparison of diameters by intensity of holdups. Thus, a 28-inch pipeline requires the lowest inlet pressure, but it has significantly higher liquid holdup compared with a 24-inch pipeline. Pressure drop comparison between 24-, 26- and 28-inch pipes does not show significant differences.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Intensity of liquid holdups with 300 MMSCFD flowrate and 24 inches internal diameter

formatted-caption.caption-text: Intensity of liquid holdups with 300 MMSCFD flowrate and 24 inches internal diameter

linkTarget.anchoringText: A nominal diameter of 26 inches with wall thickness of 0.688 inches was chosen. These values correspond to industrial pipeline with internal diameter of 24.624 inches (Megyesy, 1997), which is comparable with theoretical value of internal diameter of 24 inches obtained from the analysis. Erosion thickness is not included since the velocity-to-erosion limit ratio is always below unity, with a maximum of 0.246, as shown in Fig. 9.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Erosional velocity ratio (24 inches and 300 MMSCFD)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Erosional velocity ratio (24 inches and 300 MMSCFD)

linkTarget.anchoringText: In addition, it promotes the reduction in slug catcher size and corrosion from free water and other contaminants. Pigging removes the majority of the natural slug flow. Figure 10 presents the pigging schematics (Kolmetz, 2014).

linkTarget.bib:
Kolmetz and Kolmetz, 2014 Kolmetz
K. Kolmetz
2014. Gas Plant Slug Catcher Selection and Sizing. Kolmetz Handbook of Process Equipment Design . KLM Technology group.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Recalling, for the initial case pipeline with 36 inches and a 63579 bbl slug catcher, the pipeline was optimized to a 24-inch pipeline and lower slug catcher volume capacity in past section of this work. Theoretically, this case could be upgraded further. As an alternative solution, a pipeline multi-sizing approach is suggested. Figures 11 and 12 present results of the multi-sizing approach. Optimal combination of diameters led to a needed inlet pressure of 1247 psig (86.96 bars), which has not significant difference with previous optimization initial pressure of 1273 psig. Significant difference is found in the liquid holdup and slug volume, which is dramatically decreased from 766 bbl to 422 bbl (see Table 7.)

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Pressure Distribution for 300 MMSCFD flow rate, liquid hold-up with pipeline 24-16-24 inches and Internal diameter representation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure Distribution for 300 MMSCFD flow rate, liquid hold-up with pipeline 24-16-24 inches and Internal diameter representation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Recalling, for the initial case pipeline with 36 inches and a 63579 bbl slug catcher, the pipeline was optimized to a 24-inch pipeline and lower slug catcher volume capacity in past section of this work. Theoretically, this case could be upgraded further. As an alternative solution, a pipeline multi-sizing approach is suggested. Figures 11 and 12 present results of the multi-sizing approach. Optimal combination of diameters led to a needed inlet pressure of 1247 psig (86.96 bars), which has not significant difference with previous optimization initial pressure of 1273 psig. Significant difference is found in the liquid holdup and slug volume, which is dramatically decreased from 766 bbl to 422 bbl (see Table 7.)

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Erosional velocity ratio with pipeline profile (24-16-24 inches and 300 MMSCFD)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Erosional velocity ratio with pipeline profile (24-16-24 inches and 300 MMSCFD)
